column1: During the second half of the 19th century
column2: the city became a major lumbering center
column3: processing timber harvested in the region. Logs were floated down the Grand River to be milled in the city and shipped via the Great Lakes. The city became a center of fine wood products as well. By the end of the century
column4: it was established as the premier furniture-manufacturing city of the United States. It was nicknamed "Furniture City" and exhibited many of its products at the Centennial Exposition in Philadelphia. "After an international exhibition in Philadelphia in 1876
column5: Grand Rapids became recognized worldwide as a leader in the production of fine furniture."This event in Philadelphia
column6: attended by hundreds of thousands of people
column7: helped spark the Colonial Revival movement in American furniture. "Grand Rapids furniture" became a byword for well-made reproductions of American and English 18th and early 19th-century styles. Furniture companies included the William A. Berkey Company and its successors
column8: Baker Furniture Company
column9: Williams-Kimp
column10: and Widdicomb Furniture Company. The Grand Rapids Furniture Record was the trade paper for the city's industry. Its industries provided jobs for many new immigrants from Europe in the late 19th and early 20th century
column11: and a Polish neighborhood developed on the west side of the city.

column1: A furniture-makers' guild was established in 1931 to improve the design and craftsmanship of Grand Rapids furniture. National home furnishing markets were held in Grand Rapids for about 75 years
column2: concluding in the 1960s. By that time
column3: the furniture-making industry had largely shifted to North Carolina.Although local employment in the industry is lower than at its historic peak
column4: Grand Rapids remains a leading city in office furniture production. It incorporated trends to use steel and other manufactured materials in furniture
column5: with ergonomic designs for chairs
column6: computer stations
column7: and other furnishings.

column1: Grand Rapids developed on the banks of the Grand River
column2: where there was once a set of rapids
column3: at an altitude of 610 feet (186 m) above sea level. Ships could navigate on the river up to this fall line
column4: stopping because of the rapids. The river valley is flat and narrow
column5: surrounded by steep hills and bluffs. The terrain becomes more rolling hills away from the river. The countryside surrounding the metropolitan area consists of mixed forest and farmland
column6: with large areas of orchards to the northwest. It is approximately 25 mi (40 km) east of Lake Michigan. The state capital of Lansing lies about 60 mi (97 km) to the east-by-southeast
column7: and Kalamazoo is about 50 mi (80 km) to the south.

column1: Grand Rapids has a humid continental climate (Köppen Dfa)
column2: with very warm and humid summers
column3: cold and snowy winters
column4: and short and mild springs and autumns.

column1: Even though it is in the middle of the continent
column2: the city experiences some maritime effects due to its location east of Lake Michigan
column3: including a high number of cloudy days during the late fall and winter
column4: delayed heating in the spring
column5: delayed cooling in fall
column6: somewhat moderated temperatures during winter and lake effect snow. The city averages 75.6 in (192 cm) of snow a year
column7: making it one of the snowiest major cities in the United States. The area often receives quick and sudden lake effect snowstorms
column8: producing significant amounts of snowfall.

column2: April
column3: October and November are transitional months and the weather can vary. March has experienced a record high of 87 °F (31 °C) and record low of −8 °F (−22 °C). The average last frost date in spring is May 1
column4: and the average first frost in fall is October 11
column5: giving the area a growing season of 162 days. The city is in plant hardiness zone 6a
column6: while outlying areas are 5b. Some far western suburbs closer to the insulating effect of Lake Michigan are in zone 6b.  Summers are warm or hot
column7: and heat waves and severe weather outbreaks are common during a typical summer.

column1: The average temperature of the area is 49 °F (9 °C). The highest temperature in the area was recorded on July 13

column6: at −24 °F (−31 °C). During an average year

column8: the temperature dips to below 32 °F (0 °C). On average

column10: and 5.6 days a year have lows that are 0 °F (−18 °C) or colder.

column2: a neighborhood directly east of downtown

column4: its 1

column6: a Prairie-style home Frank Lloyd Wright designed in 1908. It was commissioned by local merchant Meyer May
column7: who operated a men's clothing store (May's of Michigan).

column1: The house is now owned and operated by Steelcase Corporation. Steelcase manufactured the furniture for the Johnson Wax Building in Racine
column2: Wisconsin
column3: which was also designed by Wright and is recognized as a landmark building. Because of those ties

=== Entertainment and performing arts ===

Grand Rapids has a number of popular concert venues in which numerous bands have performed, including 20 Monroe Live, the DAAC, the Intersection, DeVos Performance Hall, Van Andel Arena, Royce Auditorium in St. Cecilia Music Center, Forest Hills Fine Arts Center, The Pyramid Scheme, and the Deltaplex.
The Schubert Male Chorus of Grand Rapids was founded by Henry C. Post on November 19, 1883; the chorus continues to perform a variety of music.
The Grand Rapids Symphony, founded in 1930, is the largest performing arts organization in Grand Rapids with a roster of about 50 full-time and 30 part-time musicians. In addition to its own concert series, the orchestra under music director Marcelo Lehninger accompanies productions by Grand Rapids Ballet and Opera Grand Rapids, presenting more than 400 performances a year.

The Grand Rapids Barbershop Chapter Great Lakes Chorus is an all-male a cappella barbershop harmony chorus, including quartets. It is one of the oldest chapters in the Barbershop Harmony Society (formally known as the Society for the Preservation and Encouragement of Barber Shop Quartet Singing in America, or SPEBSQSA). The Grand Rapids chapter organized on November 1, 1939, for quartet singers; it is credited for holding the first society-sanctioned quartet contest in the Michigan District" (now Pioneer District) in March 1941. In 1944 the Grand Rapids Chapter is credited with having the first International Quartet champions
column21: "The Harmony Halls." In 1947 the Great Lakes Chorus (then called the Grand Rapids Chorus) was founded. In 1953 the first International Chorus Competition was held
column22: and the Great Lakes Chorus took First Place
column24:
under the direction of Robert Weaver. The chorus is still very active as a non-profit singing for community, competition, and contracted performances.
Grand Rapids Ballet Company was founded in 1971 and is Michigan's only professional ballet company. The ballet company is on Ellsworth Avenue in the Heartside neighborhood, where it moved in 2000. In 2007, it expanded its facility by adding the LEED-certified Peter Wege Theater.Opera Grand Rapids, founded in 1966, is the state's longest-running professional company. In February 2010, the opera moved into a new facility in the Fulton Heights neighborhood.A January 21, 2011 Newsweek article listed Grand Rapids as a dying city" because of its drop in population from 2000 to 2009. Director Rob Bliss and producer Scott Erickson filmed a vigorous
column26: 000-person community response. The Grand Rapids LipDub
column28: was the first-ever citywide lip dub video; film critic Roger Ebert described it as "the greatest music video ever made". The video held the world record for largest lip dub for two years and has amassed over 5 million views on YouTube; PRNewswire awarded its producers the "Earnie Award" for Best Use of Video in Social Media.Grand Rapids is also home to Art Prize
column29: the largest art exposition in the U.S. Art Prize began in 2009 with the over 200
column30: 000 visitors and has since doubled the number of visitors it receives each year. Artprize receives many international visitors each year and is still growing with over 1
column31: 500 entries from 48 countries across 200+ venues in 2015.

The Grand Rapids Police Department is tasked with law enforcement in Grand Rapids and has been serving the city since 1871. Since 2001
column2: the police department has been located at a renovated Herpolsheimer's department store at 1 Monroe Center NW. In 2011

column1: The homicide rate in Grand Rapids was at its highest in the early 1990s
column2: with the highest number of homicides being 34 in 1993. The average annual number of homicides in Grand Rapids between 2010 and 2020 was 12.4. In 2014
column3: Grand Rapids experienced the lowest homicide rate in fifty years
column4: with six murders occurring that year. By the end of the 2010s
column5: the number of homicides began to increase
column6: with a total of 17 occurring in 2019.

column2: Grand Rapids is a home rule city and adopted a city charter in 1916 providing for the council-manager form of municipal government. Under this system
column3: the political responsibilities are divided between an elected City Commission
column4: an elected City Comptroller and a hired full-time City Manager. Two part-time Commissioners are elected to four-year terms from each of three wards
column5: with half of these seats up for election every two years. The races—held in odd-numbered years—are formally non-partisan
column6: although the party and other political affiliations of candidates do sometimes come up during the campaign period. The Commission sets policy for the city
column7: and is responsible for hiring the City Manager and other appointed officials. The elected City Comptroller verifies financial policies and budgets are followed and prepares the annual financial report. The city levies an income tax of 1.5 percent on residents and 0.75 percent on nonresidents.

column1: The part-time Mayor is elected every four years by the city at large
column2: and serves as chair of the Commission
column3: with a vote equal to a Commissioner. The mayor
column4: although a weak mayor per the system of government
column5: spends approximately 20 hours per week on mayoral activities from serving on various oversight boards and attending conferences.Three-term mayor John H. Logie declined to run for re-election in 2003. Logie felt the position should be made full-time
column6: but to avoid the question becoming a referendum on whether he should hold the job full-time
column7: he announced he would not run for re-election. The voters kept the position part-time
column8: and George Heartwell succeeded him in January 2004. In 2014 a narrowly-approved ballot initiative imposed a limit of two terms on the mayor and city commissioners
column9: preventing Heartwell from seeking a fourth term. Commissioner Rosalynn Bliss
column10: also unable to run for another term in that position
column11: was then elected mayor
column12: receiving a clear majority in the August 2015 primary.

column1: The city proper and inner-suburbs favor the Democratic Party
column2: while outer-suburbs of Grand Rapids support the Republican Party.Traditionally
column3: Grand Rapids supported the Republican Party. The city is the center of the 3rd Congressional District
column4: represented by Libertarian Justin Amash. Former President Gerald Ford represented the district from 1949 to 1973 and is buried on the grounds of his Presidential Museum in Grand Rapids. The city and its suburbs are home to several major donors to the national Republican Party
column5: including the DeVos family and Peter Secchia
column6: former Ambassador to Italy.Both representatives in the Michigan State House of Representatives are Democrats
column7: and in the seven most recent presidential elections
column8: Democratic candidates Bill Clinton
column9: Al Gore
column10: John Kerry
column11: Barack Obama
column12: and Hillary Clinton won a majority or plurality of votes in the city of Grand Rapids. The last Republican candidate for President to carry the city was George H.W. Bush in 1988.

column2: toll plank road built from Kalamazoo through Wayland. It was a primary route for freight and passengers until about 1868. This road connected to other regions via the Michigan Central Railroad at Kalamazoo.
which began service in 1858

column9: Indiana

column11: Newaygo and Lake Shore Railroad completed a line to White Cloud in 1875. In 1888 the Detroit
column12: Lansing and Northern Railroad connected with Grand Rapids. Until the mid-1950s Grand Rapids Union Station was a hub for passenger trains from different directions in Michigan and beyond.
